text:
S-X2
189. Law, Ethel Jane (Mrs. Alfred)
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.)

Name ...........................................
Address ...........................................
Birthplace ...........................................

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ...........................................
Where did you set up housekeeping? ...........................................
Where had you been living before that? ...........................................
For how many people did you prepare meals? ...........................................
How far was it to your nearest store? ...........................................
How often could a visit be made to the store? ...........................................
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ...........................................

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? ...........................................
In what quantities did you buy it? ...........................................
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ...........................................
How much did you use graham flour? ...........................................
Whole wheat flour? ...........................................
Was flour milled locally? ...........................................
How far away? ...........................................
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ...........................................
What other grain products did you use? ...........................................
Cornmeal? ...........................................
Whole Wheat? ...........................................
Farina? ...........................................
Other? ...........................................

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ...........................................
How did you grind it? ...........................................
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name ...........................................

Address ...........................................

Birthplace ...........................................

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ...........................................

Where did you set up housekeeping? ...........................................

Where had you been living before that? ...........................................

For how many people did you prepare meals? ...........................................

How far was it to your nearest store? ...........................................

How often could a visit be made to the store? ...........................................

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? ...........................................

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand or white flour did you use in the early years? ...........................................

In what quantities did you buy it? ...........................................

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? ...........................................

How much did you use graham flour? ...........................................

Was flour milled locally? ...........................................

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ...........................................

What other grain products did you use? ...........................................

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ...........................................

How did you grind it? ...........................................
Harvest time sometimes 1 or more stokers fired church sent out at 4 o'clock for stokers and new cutting crop when carrying up wood for burning. sometime 3 or 4 men entire lunch taken out.
Harvest time sometimes 1 or more stockers hired
Lunches sent out at 11 o'clock for stockers and
men cutting crop.
When sawing up wood for burning, sometimes 3 or 4 men extra
lunch taken out.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy this sugar? 100 lb. bag.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $2.50.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? Armstrong & Sons White.

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? 10 lb.

At that price? $2.50.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From cows.

Butter? Made from cow's milk.

What was the price of butter? 10¢ to 25¢ lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

How? Covered with straw, kept cool, put on by hand.

Did you make butter? Yes.

Cheese? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Just ordinary cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Fresh beef raised on the farm.

How did you get fresh meat? When we killed our own.

How often did you get fresh meat? 4 or 5 times a year.

How did you preserve meat? Cured and dried.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? For 2 years only.

If so what year was it organized? 1925.

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds?

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? It was bought in winter.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh (frozen).

Kinds? White fish mostly.

One season, butter was plentiful (as market for it) farmers used it on implements instead of buying axle grease.
3. SUGAR AND SYRUP

In what quantity did you buy? ... 100 lbs. During 1906, Aug. 25th.

What was the price for a ton pound sack of white sugar? ... $1.00

Has brand of golden syrup did you use? ... Advocaat A. H. Wille

That also of tea or syrup did you usually buy? ... In the tea.

At what price? ... $1.00

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of cream during in the early days? ... Bought.

Butter? ... Made from cows milk, bought from farm.

That was the price of butter? ... 10¢ to 12¢ per lb.

Did you pack eggs for "int." ... Yes.

Did you keep fresh eggs? ... No.

Did you raise butter? ... Yes.

Did you raise cheese? ... Yes.

Did you raise milk? ... Yes.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? ... Fresh, bought.

On the farm? ... From Hagg.

How did you get fresh meat? ... Killed our own.

How often did you get fresh meat? ... 4 to 6 times a year.

How did you preserve meat? ... Packed in barrel.

Was there a "meat ring" in your neighborhood? ... For 2 years only.

If so what year was it organized? ... 1925.

Did you use game? ... Yes.

For how long? ... 1925.

What part did fish play in the family diet? ... Fish, breakfast, dinner.

Was the fish fresh, canned, or canned? ... Fresh.

Kind? ... White fish, mostly.

One reason why fish was plentiful was because of buying and selling.
6. BEVERAGES

What kind of tea did you buy? Blue Ribbons. At what price? 75 cents.

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) ________________________

Price? ____________________ What other beverages were used? _________

______________________________________________________________

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?

Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes, but never bought any from store.

If not, where from? ___________________________

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of: 1906

Potatoes __________ Cabbage __________ Carrots __________ Onions __________ Turnips __________ Beets __________

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? __________________________

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)? __________________________

What weight? __________________________ How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)? __________________________

What was the price of prunes? __________________________

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? __________________________

Peas? __________ Corn? __________ Beans? __________ Saskatoons? __________

Other foods? __________________________________________________________

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning? __________________________

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? __________________________

What year did you first preserve meat by canning? __________________________

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? __________________________

To what extent? __________________________ Did you make your own vinegar? __________________________
6. **BEVERAGES**

   - What kind of tea did you buy? Glass, R.B.T., etc.? As what's price? Yes, it's the same kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground) That other beverage? Can't recall.

7. **FOODS**

   - What was the price of potatoes at the store? $1.00 per pound. Could you get potatoes at the store? Yes, but never bought any.
   - What year did you first get your own supply for the winter of? 1906.
   - In what quantities did you buy white navy beans? 20 lbs.
   - How did you buy tomatoes? In bulk or by the box? 10 lbs. Each box.
   - How much did the grocer handle grapes (by box)? 40 lbs.
   - How much was the price of prunes? 10 cents each.
   - What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? Apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others?

8. **PRESERVING**

   - In the early years, did you preserve any foods by drying? Yes.
   - Other foods? Beans?
   - That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 1910.
   - That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 1910.
   - Do you still preserve fruits by canning or drying? Not really.
   - To what extent? About 50% of the harvest.
   - Did you make your own vinegar? No.
9. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                  | Year you first remember seeing it in the store | How was it sold? - In bulk, 10 lb. sack, can, etc. | Amt. you usually bought at one time | Price of this amount |
|-----------------------|-----------------------------------------------|---------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------|---------------------|
| Soda biscuits         | 1910                                          |                                                   | 1 lb. boxes                        |                     |
| Macaroni              |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Graham flour          |                                               |                                                   | 24 lb. each                        |                     |
| Brown sugar           |                                               | always in clock                                   | 10 lb. each                        |                     |
| Molasses              |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Table salt            |                                               |                                                   | small 1 lb. bags                   |                     |
| Common salt           |                                               |                                                   | 20 lb. bags                        |                     |
| Lily white syrup      |                                               |                                                   | 10 lb. pail                        |                     |
| Toilet soap           |                                               |                                                   | any amt required                   |                     |
| Baking powder         |                                               |                                                   | 1 lb. tins                         |                     |
| Baking soda           |                                               |                                                   | 2 x 1 lb. tins                     |                     |
| Dried peas            |                                               |                                                   | pound packages                     |                     |
| Dried corn            |                                               |                                                   | 1 gallon jars                      |                     |
| Vinegar               |                                               |                                                   | pound packages                     |                     |
| Raisins - seeded      |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| - seedless            | 1930                                          |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Rice                  |                                               | by pound                                          |                                    |                     |
| Currants              |                                               |                                                   |                                    |                     |
| Store jam - kinds?    |                                               | 4 lbs. pails, strawberry, raspberry, peach, plum etc also sold later in glass jars |                                    |                     |
| Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) | any amt |                                    |                     |
| Vanilla               |                                               | 2 x 4 oz. bottles                                 |                                    |                     |

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal

Did you make yeast for your own use? No

Using starter? No

Using hops? No

Salt rising? No

Did you buy baking powder? Yes

Baking soda? Yes

Cream of tartar? Yes

Did you make your own baking powder? No
| FOOD                  | How was it sold? | In what size? | Usually bought at bulk, 10 lb., etc., or in time? |
|-----------------------|------------------|---------------|---------------------------------------------------|
| Soda biscuits         | 1910             | 1 lb.        |                                                  |
| Macaroni              |                  |               |                                                  |
| Graham flour          |                  |               |                                                  |
| Brown sugar           | always in cloths | 10 lb. each   |                                                  |
| Molasses              |                  |               |                                                  |
| Table salt            |                  |               |                                                  |
| Common salt           |                  |               |                                                  |
| Lily white syrup      |                  |               |                                                  |
| Toilet soap           |                  |               |                                                  |
| Baking powder         |                  |               |                                                  |
| Baking soda           |                  |               |                                                  |
| Dried peas            |                  |               |                                                  |
| Dried corn            |                  |               |                                                  |
| Vinegar               |                  |               |                                                  |
| Raisins - seeded      |                  |               |                                                  |
| Rice                  | by pound         |               |                                                  |
| Currants              |                  |               |                                                  |
| Store jam - kinds?    |                  |               |                                                  |
| Cheese (Cheddar or store cheese) | any amount |               |                                                  |
| Vanilla               |                  |               |                                                  |

9. Please fill in the following on the best of your memory:

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Royal
Did you make yeast for your own use? No
Using starter? No
Using hops? No
Salt rising? No
Baking soda? Yes
Did you buy baking powder? Yes
Did you make your own baking powder? No
Cream of tartar? Yes
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                                      | Earliest date it appeared on the market | Approximate price at the time | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-------------------------------------------|----------------------------------------|------------------------------|------------------------------------------------|
| Canned salmon                             | as far back as 1906                    |                              | much cheaper than present prices                |
| Canned sardines                           |                                        |                              |                                                 |
| Other canned fish that appeared early - give names |                                        |                              |                                                 |
| Apples - fresh                            | 1912                                   |                              | always in stock in winter                       |
| - dried                                   |                                        |                              |                                                 |
| Lettuce                                   |                                        |                              |                                                 |
| Tomatoes - fresh                          |                                        |                              | always in stock from as early as 1906           |
| - canned                                  |                                        |                              |                                                 |
| Bananas                                   |                                        |                              |                                                 |
| Lemons                                    | 1910                                   |                              |                                                 |
| Oranges                                   | 1910                                   |                              |                                                 |
| Cornflakes                                | 1910                                   |                              |                                                 |
| Other prepared breakfast cereals - give names |                                        |                              | puffed wheat & rice, brown flakes 1912          |
| Pearl tapioca                             | in stock from earliest days            |                              |                                                 |
| Minute tapioca                            |                                        |                              |                                                 |
| Sago                                      |                                        |                              |                                                 |
| Dates                                     | 1915                                   |                              |                                                 |
| Walnuts                                   | early days in winter                   |                              |                                                 |
| Icing sugar                               | from earliest days                     |                              |                                                 |

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, slough, dugout) ... well ..................................................................

How far was this water from your home? ... ¼ mile ...........................................

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ... barrel ...........................................

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Fresh water hauled for 32 years
soft water from sloughs or caught in barrels when rain came
winter time used snow for soft water, later blocks of ice were saved from the sloughs and hauled to house for melting for soft water.
11. PLEASE FILL IN THE FOLLOWING TO THE BEST OF YOUR MEMORY:

| FOOD                        | Approximate date it appeared on the market | How did it differ from the same product today? |
|-----------------------------|--------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------|
| Canned salmon               |                                            |                                                |

| Oranges                     | 1910                                       |                                                |

| Other prepared breakfast cereals - give names | Pearl tapioca in stock from earliest days |
| Minute tapioca              |                                            |                                                |
| Sago                        | 1915                                       |                                                |
| Dates                       |                                            |                                                |
| Walnuts                     | early days in winter                       |                                                |
| Icing sugar                 | from earliest days                         |                                                |

12. WATER SUPPLY

Where did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (well, river, stream, dugout) ... well ...

How far was this water from your home? ... 4 mile ...

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) ... tank ...

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Fresh water hauled for 32 years

Water line used once for soft water, later block of ice were drawn from the spring and hauled to house for melting for soft water.
13. SOAPS

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? ... made most of my own.

If you made your own, did you use lye? ... yes, wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? ... suds, lye, etc.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? ... wood for summer, coal for winter.

Where did you get your fuel? ... early days used coal, then grew our own wood cut down in winter.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

In summer for quick cooking used cow manure from pasture, then later while clover was growing we used wood from trees planted round the buildings.

Some cord wood bought in early days.

My brother and husband drove 50 miles to Cunningham Manor and chopped wood from the bush and hauled on sledges for wood for summer use round trip 100 miles.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) ... indoor cook stove from 1904 to leaving the farm.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) ...

By whom was your first cook stove made? ... circular (name).

What year was it purchased? ... 1908 ... Price? ... $42.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) ... iron for soap making, general for general cooking, etc.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) ... wooden bowl for working up butter.

When did you first see enamel ware? ... 1910.

Aluminum? ... 1915.
13. SOAP
Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made a lot of my own.
If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, wood ash.
What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Soap made by hand.

14. FUEL
What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood for cooking, coal for heating.
Where did you get your fuel? From the woods near our home.
Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.
In summer, we used wood for cooking and coal for heating.
Then later, when we moved to the building, we used wood for cooking and coal for heating.
My brother and I helped build an adobe house for winter use around 1910-1915.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS
For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? Open hearth from 1906 to 1917.
Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates)
By whom was your first cook stove made? L. A. Smith (L.A.S.)
What year was it purchased? 1908
What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homeware)
For preparing food? (Glass, earthenware, wooden bowls, other)
When did you first see enamel ware? 1910
Aluminum? 1915
16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

From cardboard containers to cellophane 1920

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

1923
Breakfast cooked cereal toast syrup or jam with milk
Dinner meat with potatoes and one other veg, carrots, onions, (peas or beans cabbage in summer)
bread, pudding rice, corned beef or pie
apple pie, loganberry, pumpkin (more meat) Xmas
supper mostly cold meat, eggs, potatoes, preserved fruit

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? 1911.
Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Husband & myself. 35 - 31. One child 4 years old
Brother-in-law & his-in-law. 33 - 32.
Two children 1 three
1 five

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

Never.
Supplies were few in early days but we always had meat, bread & common vegetables also milk & butter. Eggs, salads very rare. Lettuce & radishes grown in summer.
16. TYPICAL DAYS AND CONTAINERS

Recite any changes which you recall in the wrapping and containers received with the food purchased (give dates where possible).

Your cardboard container to asleep 1930

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: corned beef, toast, apple jam

Dinner: meat with potatoes and one other vegetable

Supper: meat, pudding, tea, corned beef

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner? In Western Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Husband aged 35 - 31
Brother-in-law aged 35 - 32

Two children aged 1 - five

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation? Toast, no sugar, no oats or two. Locally produced foods? Give details. News.

Supplies were few in early days but we always had meat, bread, common vegetables also milked butter.
Ques. 17

In cold weather often had pancakes, potato patties, etc., etc.

potatoes or potatoes fried in deep fat.
Dec 17

In cold weather often had pancakes, potato patties, chips etc., scallop potatoes & potatoes fried in deep fat.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There were more boiled sweet puddings in earlier days which took longer to cook. We had no one minute rice or caramel pudding powders. However, we could get jelly powders. Rice pudding cooked on top of stove then finished off in oven.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I used home grown foods until I left farm in 1942. Even yet I do not use many prepared foods except in real hot weather. I have not baked any bread since leaving farm 1942.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Some years raspberries (home grown) were plentiful also cranberries, currants, blackberries, wild plums, choke, cherries which were picked from bushes at a distance from farm 10-20 miles. Jelly could be made from choke cherries & cranberries. We used to buy enough flour after harvest to do till next harvest very often stored in some corner of bedroom. Groceries were often bought in large quantities from Eaton's when the crop was sold. Items such as sugar, syrup, oatmeal, flour etc. 100 lb order came cheaper by freight.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

There were none before we had electricity early days which took longer to cook. We had no microwave or basement cooking facilities.

Now we can get jelly powders. Rice for eating cooked on top of stove then finished off in oven.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I used home grown foods until I left farm in 1942. Since then I do not use many prepared foods except in bad hot weather.

I have not baked any bread since leaving farm.

1942

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

Some year vegetables (home grown) were plentiful also. Cucumbers, well known, cloths, chives, which were fresh from truck at a distance from farm 15-20 miles.

Jelly could be made from choke cherry and prunes.

We used to buy enough flour after harvest to do till next harvest very often stored in some corner of bedroom.

Groceries were often bought in large quantities from Eaton's when the crop was sold. New such as sugar, syrup, oatmeal, flour etc.

In the order came cheaper by freight.
Oxford

No. 613 S

If Slimtrim Fasteners are to be included, please specify.

Spécifiez si vous voulez des agrafes Slimtrim.

Mississauga, Ontario L5T 1M8
